In both cities, some protesters, including those at the Philadelphia site, expressed a desire to continue their cause and criticized the city's handling of the situation. The mayor of Los Angeles, Antonio Villaraigosa, had initially allowed the occupation but eventually set a midnight deadline for the protesters to move. However, the mayor and police chief decided to allow the Los Angeles encampment to remain open until at least the next day, possibly due to a lack of immediate enforcement. answers: The Occupy LA encampment got a stay of execution this morning—though a few arrests have been reported beyond the boundaries of City Hall Park. At around 5am, police told protesters over a loudspeaker that they didn't intend to clear the park, the LA Times reports. Police do, however, intend to clear protesters out of the street, and several people who refused to move out of an intersection have already been arrested. "We definitely need to get morning traffic in," a police commander explained. Everything also seems calm at Occupy Philadelphia, where protesters defied a 5pm Sunday deadline to disperse. But as of last night, a police inspector said they didn't intend to forcibly evict anyone. "We look forward to working with Occupy Philadelphia and a resolution of the problem," he told the Philadelphia Inquirer. "Confrontation is never good."

pred: Mikhail Kalashnikov, the inventor of the AK-47 assault rifle, expressed in a letter to the Russian Orthodox Church Patriarch Kirill before his death that he felt morally responsible for the lives lost due to his weapon. With over 100 million Kalashnikovs sold worldwide, the gun's widespread use has raised questions about its impact on conflicts and the inventor's own spiritual pain. Kalashnikov, who was baptized and attended church, believed his rifle was designed to defend his country but wondered if his creation contributed to the loss of innocent lives. The Russian Orthodox Church has a position that supports the use of weapons for national defense, as stated by Patriarch Kirill's press secretary. Kalashnikov's legacy, along with the AK-47's enduring popularity, highlights the complex relationship between innovation, warfare, and the personal consequences for its creators.
answers: In our own obituary of AK-47 inventor Mikhail Kalashnikov last month, we included this quote: The rifle was invented "for the protection of the Motherland," he said. "I have no regrets and bear no responsibility for how politicians have used it." It turns out "no regrets" might not have exactly been true. The AFP picks up a report from Russia's Izvestia that Kalashnikov penned a letter to the head of the Russian Orthodox Church nine months before his December death in which he wrote of "unbearable ... spiritual pain" and asked about his culpability. It contains this line: "I keep having the same unsolved question: if my rifle took away people's lives, then can it be that I ... am guilty for people's deaths, even if they were enemies?" AFP notes that Izvestia ran a copy of the letter, which is typed on Kalashnikov's personal stationery and signed "with a wavering hand." A rep for Patriarch Kirill confirms that the letter was sent, and says the church leader wrote a reply—one that very may well have calmed his fears. Says the rep, "The Church has a very definite position: when weapons serve to protect the Fatherland, the Church supports both its creators and the soldiers who use it." But the BBC notes that it's not clear whether every word came from Kalashnikov: Izvestia reports that his daughter believes a priest helped him write the letter.

answers: Unnamed officials say TSA officer Gerardo Hernandez lay bleeding for 33 minutes at LAX before being taken to an ambulance. Now under review: the conversations took place between police and fire commanders to determine when it was safe enough to enter, and whether paramedics could have gone into the terminal earlier. While an officer who checked on Hernandez about 5 minutes after he was shot told numerous officers he was dead, the AP reports that it's not known whether that officer had the training needed to make that determination; no first-aid was administered. pred: Jack McCullough, a man convicted in the 1957 murder of 7-year-old Maria Ridulph, has had his conviction overturned due to "clear and convincing evidence" presented by the prosecutor, DeKalb County State's Attorney Richard Schmack. The judge ruled that the original trial was flawed, including false testimony and an altered timeline. McCullough, now 76, was released from prison and flashed a private signal to his stepdaughter, expressing "I love you," as he was taken away. answers: A man convicted four years ago in the oldest cold case ever tried was freed Friday after an Illinois judge vacated his conviction and subsequent life sentence, CNN reports. According to CBS News, 76-year-old Jack McCullough was convicted of kidnapping a 7-year-old girl, choking her, and stabbing her to death in 1957. The case was reopened in 2008, and McCullough was arrested in 2011 and convicted the following year. After an appeal by McCullough, Illinois state's attorney Richard Schmack launched a six-month investigation that found what he calls "clear and convincing evidence" that McCullough is innocent. While the judge Friday vacated McCullough's conviction, he stopped short of declaring him innocent, and a new trial will be held, the Chicago Tribune reports. McCullough, who lived in the same neighborhood as the kidnapped girl, says he was 40 miles away at an Air Force recruiting center at the time of the kidnapping. It's an alibi that passed a polygraph test in 1957 and made it impossible for him to be the culprit based on the FBI's original timeline for the kidnapping. That timeline was later changed by police, and Schmack says documents—including phone and Air Force records—supporting McCullough's alibi were wrongly not allowed at his trial. A friend of the kidnapped girl picked McCullough out of a photo lineup when the case was reopened. But his was the only non-yearbook photo in the lineup, and she picked a different man out of a photo lineup 50 years earlier. That info wasn't allowed at McCullough's trial either. No physical evidence was ever found to support McCullough's conviction.

Two recent studies, published in the journal Infection and Immunity, reveal the harmful effects of cigarette smoke on antibiotic-resistant bacteria, particularly Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). Researchers from the University of California, San Diego School of Medicine found that exposure to cigarette smoke increases the resistance of MRSA to antibiotics and makes it more aggressive, as it can evade immune responses by altering its cell walls.

In the first study, led by Dr. Laura E. Crotty Alexander, MRSA exposed to cigarette smoke exhibited a resistance to reactive oxygen species, which are normally used by immune cells to fight off infections. The bacteria were also more resistant to antimicrobial peptides, making it harder for the immune system to eliminate them.烟雾中的MRSA细胞壁发生改变，使其对抗生素更具有抵抗力，且这种抵抗性的持久性长达24小时，即使在体外实验中，暴露于烟雾的MRSA对人类细胞更具侵袭性。

The second study, conducted by the same team, investigated the effects of e-cigarette vapor on MRSA and found that while it also made the bacteria more resistant, the increase in resistance was less pronounced compared to cigarette smoke. Cigarette smoke, in particular, appears to function as a "alarm" for MRSA, triggering it to adapt and become more resilient.

These findings suggest that cigarette smoke not only harms smokers but also contributes to the spread and persistence of antibiotic-resistant bacteria, potentially increasing the severity of infections in hospital settings and the overall difficulty in treating MRSA. The researchers emphasize the importance of quitting smoking as a preventive measure against the increased resistance of MRSA and other infections.
answers: Superbugs such as MRSA are already bad enough. But it turns out that something can make them even nastier: cigarette smoke. Researchers found that antibiotic-resistant bacteria exposed to the smoke became more aggressive and far more difficult to kill, they explain at Eureka Alert. It's almost as if the smoke sets off an alarm that causes the bacteria to strengthen its defenses, explains the Union-Tribune of San Diego. Scientists made the discovery by exposing immune cells to two different batches of MRSA, one normal and one treated with cigarette smoke extract. The bigger the dose of smoke, the bigger the effect, notes Medical Daily. "We already know that smoking cigarettes harms human respiratory and immune cells, and now we've shown that, on the flipside, smoke can also stress out invasive bacteria and make them more aggressive," says lead author Laura Crotty Alexander of UC San Diego. It's a double-whammy: Smokers already have weakened immune systems that make them more susceptible to infectious diseases, and the smoke they inhale seems to make invading pathogens even more dangerous. In this study, the smoke helped MRSA survive longer and kill more mice with pneumonia. (The latest antibiotic-resistant bug to make headlines is a nasty stomach virus.)

In a study led by University of Toulouse's Young-Ho Eom, the most influential person in the English-language world, as determined by Wikipedia articles, is found to be Frank Sinatra. However, the results of the analysis, which used Google's PageRank algorithm, were initially surprising due to the inclusion of 18th-century Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus as the top-ranked figure. Linnaeus, known as the "Father of Taxonomy," scored high due to the extensive presence of scientific names on Wikipedia, particularly in the field of taxonomy.

The study aimed to investigate if Wikipedia's attention to figures was biased by factors like gender, time, or location. It discovered that most significant historical figures across Wikipedia language editions were born in Western countries after the 17th century and were predominantly male, with Adolf Hitler taking the second spot after Michael Jackson. The algorithm seemed to favor Linnaeus due to the abundance of scientific articles linking to him.

To address the issue with Linnaeus' high ranking, researchers employed a modified measure called CheiRank, which considers both incoming and outgoing links, to rank individuals. This method, combined with PageRank, resulted in a new ranking system called 2DRank, where Frank Sinatra was still ranked first, followed by Linnaeus.

The study also revealed that the Internet Archive is conducting crawls to preserve web pages and their references, with the goal of fixing broken links and maintaining a record of the original content. In a separate study, the most influential thinker in the world, as determined by Wikipedia, was again surprising, with Linnaeus topping the list, beating out notable figures like historical figures, politicians, and even Jesus Christ.

Overall, the news highlights the quirks of Wikipedia's page ranking system, the importance of historical figures in specific fields, and the ongoing efforts to preserve and analyze the influence of these figures on the web.
answers: Using methods borrowed from Google, a group of researchers has analyzed all Wikipedia pages and determined that, at least on the English language version of the site, Frank Sinatra is the world's most important person. Second place goes to Michael Jackson, and third to Pope Pius XII. When factoring in all 24 language editions of the online encyclopedia, the team found that Adolf Hitler ranked the most important person, while Michael Jackson was again second and Madonna third, reports the Guardian. "Our analysis shows that most important historical figures across Wikipedia language editions are born in western countries after the 17th century, and are male," the authors write. The researchers combined two algorithms to reach these conclusions. First, Google's PageRank algorithm, which determines a page's importance based on how many other pages link to it. In using PageRank on Wikipedia, the most important person in the world was 18th-century Swedish naturalist Carl Linnaeus, likely because the pages of organism after organism link back to the "father of taxonomy." So the researchers added an algorithm called CheiRank, which determines importance based on the number of outgoing links, the thought being that an important person would himself be connected to other important people, things, and events. Using the two together—an approach they dubbed 2DRank—no one beat out Frank Sinatra on English pages or Adolf Hitler across all language versions. Last year, in a separate study analyzing academic references, one team deemed Karl Marx to be the world's most important scholar, according to the Smithsonian. (Click to read about one of Sinatra's quirks.)

But a new study reported in the Journal of Forensic Sciences finds the bloodstain image was likely faked. The nearly complete fossil, found in the Tiaojishan Formation, revealed iridescent structures in the head, neck, and chest, suggesting the presence of rainbow-like colors. Caihong's feathers, with their distinct barbs and vanes, displayed a unique pattern that aligns with the nanostructures found in some modern bird species, particularly in hummingbirds. These nanostructures, which are thought to be melanosomes, indicate that the dinosaur had a range of colors, including shades of grey and black, as well as vibrant hues.

The presence of a crest and a bird-like body with flight feathers, but a non-avian pelvis, suggests that Caihong may have glided or flown, possibly from trees to hunt small mammals. The study's authors propose that the dinosaur's tail feathers, which were particularly well-preserved, could have played a role in aerodynamics.

This discovery challenges the traditional understanding of dinosaur feather evolution, as it represents the earliest known creature with asymmetrical feathers, a trait used in modern birds for flight. The researchers also note that the fossil's feathers, despite being well-preserved, may not have fully preserved their original colors due to compaction during fossilization.

In summary, Caihong juji, the "rainbow dinosaur," is a significant find that adds to our understanding of dinosaur feather diversity and the potential functions of iridescent plumage in these ancient creatures. Further research is needed to unravel the specific roles these feathers played in the animal's behavior and lifestyle.

The study in the journal Nature Communications documenting the find explains that "Caihong" means "rainbow" in Mandarin. Scientists think the colorful plumage, which appeared to have covered the bony-crested creature's head, neck, and chest areas, may have kept the dinosaur warm, as well as attracted potential mates; National Geographic compares it to peacock feathers. So how were researchers able to tell what color feathers the creature had from preserved bones? They used high-tech microscopes able to home in on 66 sites on the fossil, detecting tiny cell structures called melanosomes, which underlie pigmentation. Which colors they led to can be found by their shapes, and the melanosomes in Caihong were long and flat like pancakes—similar to those found in hummingbirds, which boast iridescent plumage. Although they can't pick out from the Pantone wheel Caihong's exact colors, researchers say the creature likely sported feathers with a "rainbow glimmer." Study co-author Xing Zu tells National Geographic that Caihong was a predator that spent its days gliding from tree to tree. And "glide" is the operative word, as this dinosaur likely didn't fly: Its feathers were located on its tail, not on its wings like birds, Discover notes. (A study postulated that nearly all dinosaurs had feathers.)

A new study published in the American Medical Association journal JAMA Pediatrics has found a potential link between acetaminophen, commonly used in pregnancy to relieve pain and treat fever, and an increased risk of ADHD in children. Pregnant women who frequently took acetaminophen, also known as Tylenol, were found to have a 29% higher risk of having a child diagnosed with ADHD and a 37% higher risk of hyperkinetic syndrome, a rarer diagnosis. The study, which analyzed data from 64,000 Danish children and their mothers, suggests that acetaminophen use during pregnancy may be associated with the development of these conditions, but it's not the sole factor. Other factors, such as underlying infections or genetic predispositions, cannot be ruled out. McNeil Consumer Healthcare, the manufacturer of Tylenol, stated in a statement that they are aware of the study but emphasize that there are no current randomized controlled studies linking acetaminophen use to adverse effects on child development. Dr. Jeff Chapa, from Cleveland Clinic Children's Hospital, suggests that while acetaminophen is generally safe, pregnant women should consider alternative methods for managing pain if necessary.

The finding has sparked a debate among experts, with some, like Dr. Max Wiznitzer, associating the link to potential hormonal effects during pregnancy and genetic predispositions. He advises against making definitive conclusions based on the study alone, as ADHD has multiple contributing factors, including genetic and environmental influences.

In summary, the study raises concerns about acetaminophen use in pregnancy, but more research is needed to confirm a causal relationship. Pregnant women are encouraged to weigh the risks and discuss medication options with their healthcare providers.

The risk increased the later in pregnancy the drug was taken and the longer it was taken. A black Range Rover, believed to be involved in an altercation at a nearby casino, opened fire on a Maserati, causing a fiery crash that involved a taxi and resulted in the deaths of the taxi driver and two passengers. The driver of the Maserati also died in the crash. The suspect vehicle, with dark tinted windows and missing license plates, fled the scene.

The shooting took place near the intersection of Las Vegas Boulevard and Flamingo Road, a busy area with multiple casinos, including the Bellagio, Caesars Palace, and Bally's. Police are investigating the incident and have contacted authorities in neighboring states to search for the Range Rover. The motive for the shooting is believed to have originated from an altercation at an unspecified casino.

A witness, Mark Thompson from the UK, compared the incident to a scene from a movie, describing it as "unprecedented" and "not what you expect in a place like Las Vegas." The police are examining surveillance footage and interviewing witnesses to piece together the events leading up to the shooting.

The incident marked the second violent event on the Strip in the same year, following a shooting at a parking garage and a stabbing at The Hotel at Mandalay Bay. The Las Vegas Convention and Visitors Authority's spokesperson, Jeremy Handel, assured the public that the city remains a safe destination, but the violence has raised concerns among tourists.

The investigation continues, with police searching for the Range Rover and questioning witnesses. The area around the scene was closed for most of the day as crime scene investigators worked to collect evidence. The incident has sparked memories of past violent incidents on the Strip, such as the 1996 shooting of Tupac Shakur.
answers: Police in three states are still hunting for a Range Rover whose occupants opened fire on another car on the Vegas Strip this morning and set off a deadly chain reaction. Cops don't know most of the details, but they say it started with a dispute of some kind in one of the nearby hotels, then spilled into the street, reports the Las Vegas Sun. When the Range Rover caught up to a Maserati at a stop light, shots were fired from the SUV that sent the Maserati crashing into a taxi, which exploded upon impact. Three people—the Maserati driver, the taxi driver, and a taxi passenger—were killed, and three others were injured, reports the LA Times. Police are hoping to piece together more details by interviewing a passenger in the Maserati, who was injured in the melee. Earlier reports that gunfire came from both vehicles as part of a moving shootout were incorrect. The AP collects this quote from a tourist visiting from Manchester, England: "This doesn't happen where we come from, not on this scale. We get stabbings, and gang violence, but this is like something out of a movie. Like Die Hard or something."

Autumn Veatch was on a small plane with her step-grandparents that crashed after departing Kalispell, Mont., on Saturday afternoon, the Bellingham Herald reports. There was no sign of the plane or its occupants until a motorist found Veatch on State Route 20 yesterday afternoon and took her to a general store, where employees called authorities, the AP reports. "She did joke that it was a good thing she'd watched all those Survivor shows that she didn't like, but her dad made her watch anyway," a family friend tells the Seattle Times. The news report covers two main stories related to the music industry and environmental regulation. The first story revolves around the Justice Department's raid on Gibson Guitar Corporation, accusing them of trafficking in illegally obtained wood. This is based on the company's alleged violation of the Lacey Act, a federal law that regulates the trade of endangered species, including plants. The raid took place in August 2011, causing significant disruption to the company's operations and leading to a conflict between Gibson and the government over the legality of their actions.

Gibson CEO Henry Juszkiewicz disputes the claims, stating that the company has not been charged and is working to prove its compliance. The Lacey Act requires end users to verify the legality of their wood supply chains, but the report suggests that there may be discrepancies in the law's interpretation.

The second part of the summary mentions that since 1996, Alexa Internet has been donating their crawl data to the Internet Archive, which helps preserve web content over time. This data, known as the Wayback Machine, allows users to access older versions of websites that may no longer be available through regular search engines.

In summary, the news highlights the legal challenges faced by Gibson Guitar due to the Lacey Act and the impact on the company's operations, as well as the ongoing issue of ensuring compliance with environmental regulations in the context of the internet's historical preservation through the Wayback Machine.
answers: Allegations of illegal wood imports prompted the Justice Department to raid Gibson Guitar facilities in Tennessee last week. NPR aired the complicated story involving the 100-year old Lacey Act, which prohibits imports of endangered species, including plants, into the US. No formal charges have been pressed, but it appears the issue lies with Gibson possibly importing banned Madagascar ebony. Gibson insists the wood confiscated by marshals was legally acquired rosewood from India. Adding some gusto to the story, right-leaning sites assert that Gibson rival CF Martin uses the same wood in some of its guitars, but the company was never investigated. The Landmark Report thinks that's fishy, given that Martin's CEO is a Democratic donor and Gibson's CEO is a GOP backer. Raising the octave even higher, it is possible Michelle Obama ran afoul of the Lacey Act when she presented France's Carla Bruni with a Gibson guitar that may have contained banned wood. However the story plays out, many are frustrated with the retroactive aspect of the law. "It's a nightmare," says a dealer. "I can't help it if they used Brazilian rosewood on almost every guitar made prior to 1970."

These incidents serve as a reminder of the importance of rabies prevention, as the virus can be fatal if left untreated. Animals with symptoms of rabies, such as aggression or unusual behavior, should be avoided, and individuals who are bitten should seek medical attention immediately, as Borch did, by drowning the animal in a case of a raccoon attack or reporting the incident to authorities.

Both Borch and the man who was bitten by the fox have received necessary vaccinations and treatments to prevent further infection. The risk of rabies remains, and the local authorities emphasize the need for awareness and caution when encountering potentially infected animals.
answers: Rachel Borch was out for a jog in the woods near her home in Hope, Maine, when a "ferocious-looking" attacker with beady eyes and tiny teeth made a beeline for her, reports the Camden Herald. Borch, 21, knew immediately that something was wrong with the raccoon that was charging toward her. "Imagine the Tasmanian devil," she tells the Bangor Daily News of the "terrifying" June 3 incident. Yanking out her headphones, she began "dancing" around the animal on the narrow path, but she tells the Herald she knew that, one way or another, the animal was going to bite her. She figured her hands would be the best spot, so she offered them up. The raccoon chomped down on her thumb and stayed there, scratching at her legs and arms as she screamed. Now on her knees, she spotted her phone lying submerged in a mud puddle, and had an idea: drown it. "With my thumb in its mouth, I just pushed its head down into the muck," she tells the News. When the raccoon finally stopped moving, she yanked out her finger and raced the three-quarters of a mile home. Two days later, the state confirmed the animal was infected with rabies. Borch got rabies shots, and an animal control officer adds an unpleasant footnote: The infected raccoon may not be alone. In recent news, researchers have discovered significant evidence of a large ancient ocean on Mars, suggesting that the planet was more habitable in its youth. A team from NASA, using powerful telescopes, found that a massive ocean covering around 20% of the northern hemisphere, similar to Earth's Atlantic, existed 4.5 billion years ago. The water was estimated to be up to 137 meters deep, with a high concentration of deuterium, a heavy isotope of hydrogen, indicating a global equivalent water layer.

The study, published in the journal Science, revealed that Mars had a more extensive water presence than previously thought, with a global ocean covering a fifth of the planet's surface. The deuterium enrichment in the polar regions suggests that water on Mars was significantly enriched in deuterium, reaching up to 8 times Earth's standard, or VSMOW, ratio. This high level of deuterium indicates that Mars may have had a more substantial water reservoir during its early history.

The presence of a global ocean on Mars challenges the conventional understanding that the planet was largely dry and uninhabitable. The inferred water loss due to the leakage of hydrogen into space has led to a higher concentration of deuterium in the remaining water, which is now concentrated in the northern low-lying plains. The discovery of such a large body of water strengthens the case for the possibility of past habitability on Mars.

Methane detection by the Mars rover Curiosity has also been mentioned, raising questions about the potential for life on the planet. However, the exact origin and persistence of methane are still under investigation. The combination of these findings underscores Mars' potential for ancient habitability, but the exact amount of water and the likelihood of life remain subjects of ongoing research and debate among scientists.
answers: Imagine all the water in the Arctic Ocean. Now, imagine all that and more on Mars. If you visited the Red Planet roughly 4.3 billion years ago, that's what you likely would have found, say NASA scientists. Their new study arrived at that "solid estimate ... by determining how much water was lost to space," says lead author Geronimo Villanueva. The Guardian reports the scientists used three powerful infrared telescopes to analyze two forms of water in Mars' atmosphere: H2O and HDO, in which deuterium (aka "heavy" hydrogen) has taken the place of one hydrogen atom. As National Geographic explains, Mars' gravity is weaker than our own; that allowed hydrogen to escape from the atmosphere and into space over time, boosting the amount of deuterium in its water. Scientists compared the ratio of HDO to H2O in Martian water today with that in water from a 4.5 billion-year-old Mars meteorite to arrive at their conclusions, a press release states. They ultimately calculated that Mars was once home to 20 million cubic kilometers of ocean. It could have covered every inch of the planet in water 450 feet deep, but the scientists think a different scenario is more likely: that the ocean covered roughly a fifth of the planet, was located in the northern hemisphere, and was as much as a mile deep. While National Geographic observes the findings back up "reams of earlier evidence that water once existed on the surface" of Mars, another study author points out the assessment of the degree of water lost indicates something new. "The planet was very likely wet for a longer period of time than was previously thought, suggesting it might have been habitable for longer," a scientist says. (Mysterious plumes on Mars are stumping scientists.)

In 2014, a Lund University Analytical Chemistry professor, Charlotta Turner, received a distressing message from her student Firas Jumaah, who was in hiding from the Islamic State (ISIS) in Iraq due to the group's attack on his hometown. Jumaah, a Yazidi minority, and his family were in grave danger. Turner, moved by Jumaah's situation, contacted the university's security head, Per Gustafson, who immediately arranged a rescue operation involving a security company. Within a few days, two Landcruisers rescued Jumaah, his wife, and their children from the hiding place, safely transporting them to Erbil and eventually back to Sweden.

Firas Jumaah, despite being a student at Lund University, had voluntarily returned to Iraq during the crisis to be with his family. His wife's fear for their safety led to Jumaah's plea for Turner to withdraw him from his thesis, as he feared he might not survive the ongoing conflict. Turner's intervention and Gustafson's swift action not only saved Jumaah but also secured the lives of his family, who had survived the atrocities committed by ISIS.

Jumaah, after returning to Sweden, completed his PhD and now works in the pharmaceutical industry. The university's involvement in this extraordinary rescue operation, which involved hiring a security company and arranging a global transport, marked a rare instance where a university played a direct role in protecting its student during a war-torn situation. This incident highlights the resilience and compassion of Turner and the university's commitment to its students' well-being.
answers: Four years ago, a chemistry professor got a text from her grad student: If I'm not back in a week, cut me from the doctoral program. Charlotta Turner called him right away: "He was very sad and crying,” the 48-year-old prof at Lund University in Sweden tells NBC News. "I could hear that the situation was hopeless and they had to flee." The student, Firas Jumaah, was visiting his native Iraq to help family members during a brutal 2014 ISIS attack targeting Yazidis—a religious minority that includes his family. The terror group had just enslaved and massacred Yazidis by the thousand in nearby Sinjar. Now Jumaah and family were planning to flee to the mountains. "I had no hope at all," says Jumaah, per the Local. "I was desperate." But Turner took action. She spoke to Lund University's then-security chief, who contacted a company that sent mercenaries into northern Iraq. Only days later, four armed mercs on two Landcruisers blazed into the place where Jumaah was hiding, and rushed him to Erbil Airport with his wife and two young kids. "I have never felt so privileged, so VIP," he says. "But at the same time I felt like a coward as I left my mother and sisters behind me." Seeing his colleagues back in Sweden, he was speechless: "I just cried," he says. Yet Jumaah finished his PhD and found work at a Malmo pharmaceuticals company, and his family survived. The bill: roughly 60,000 kroner ($6,613), which his family has nearly finished paying. “If they told me to pay 200,000 kronor, I would,” says Jumaah. (The UN is finding fresh ISIS horrors.)

The movie, marketed as a con artist thriller, is described as a "sleight of hand" that fails to deliver on its promise of a real and insightful portrayal of the con artist world. Will Smith plays Nicky, a seasoned con artist, and Margot Robbie's character, Jess, is a young apprentice who becomes involved in his schemes. The review points out that the film's attempts to create a seductive atmosphere, particularly in the chemistry between Smith and Robbie, are the only redeeming qualities. However, the movie's narrative is criticized for being absurd and illogical, with a confusing mix of elements that make it difficult to follow.

One scene in the film, featuring a scene withBD Wong, is highlighted as a standout moment due to its captivating performance. The reviewer notes that while the film has some amusing moments and a talented supporting cast, the central relationship between Smith and Robbie lacks depth, as their interactions seem forced and the characters' motivations are unclear.

The casting of Will Smith and Margot Robbie in the roles, despite initial interest from high-profile actors like Ben Affleck and Jennifer Lawrence, is seen as a successful pairing that brings a touch of lightheartedness to the otherwise dull genre. The movie's director, John Requa and Glenn Ficarra, are praised for allowing Smith to showcase his natural charm without relying solely on his usual serious demeanor.

In conclusion, "Focus" is a film that, while attempting to captivate audiences with its premise, falls short in delivering a compelling story and fails to live up to its potential. Despite the presence of talented actors like Smith and Robbie, the movie's lack of substance and overreliance on charm and spectacle is the main critique.
answers: Will Smith stars as Nicky, an established con man who takes on a new apprentice, Australian newcomer Margot Robbie's Jess, in Focus. They both love the con game, but who's playing who? Here's what critics are saying: Richard Corliss at Time is a fan. "The mix of longtime star and minx on the rise is one tasty element in the success of a movie that approaches the modest goals and effortless allure of a 60-year-old Hitchcock," he writes. Smith "takes a welcome break from glowering sci-fi roles" and writer-directors Glenn Ficarra and John Requa "deserve some credit in letting Will be Will in the star's first charm barrage since 2005's Hitch." Steven Rea at the Philadelphia Inquirer admits Smith "shows some of the movie-star wattage that's been missing from his recent pics. He charms." There's also "combustible chemistry" between Smith and Robbie, but the movie just "disappoints," Rea writes. "Even if you're willing to forgive its sinkhole plotholes and farthest-fetched conceits, the film ... ultimately makes no sense." Betsy Sharkey, on the other hand, says this "rom-com-con" is "an irresistible reminder of all the reasons we first fell for the Fresh Prince so many years ago." Writing at the Los Angeles Times, she notes the romantic role of Nicky fits Smith perfectly, while Robbie is "more than holding her own" as his match. "The scams are Rubik's Cube complicated, but what keeps you guessing is whether the romantic connection between Jess and Nicky is real or just another con." But Mick LaSalle at the San Francisco Chronicle isn't convinced. In a review titled "Will Smith just stole $12 from your pocket," he argues Focus is "ridiculous in every detail. It's a movie with no truth that teaches nothing and shows nothing, that has only its audacity to recommend it." Nicky and Jess lack "impact," partly because "Smith is not a strong leading man," he says. Viewers are left "waiting for the trick, which is not the same as being fooled."

answers: Dinosaurs may have been much more like modern birds than we knew—and not just because some had feathers. As the scientists explain in the journal Evolution, per UT News, the sound actually comes out of the neck area after air is pushed through an esophageal pouch. In fact, the animal's mouth is shut the whole time. Lots of birds do this today, and because birds descended from dinosaurs, scientists suspect they may have communicated in a similar way. The fossil record can't prove it, though the Washington Post notes that previous research meshes with the idea, including the belief that dinosaurs had air sacs instead of vocal chords. “A cool thing about this work is the demonstration that closed-mouth behavior evolved many times,” says the lead author. “That suggests it can emerge fairly easily and be incorporated into mating displays" among different types of animals. Supermoon enthusiasts can enjoy the spectacle without leaving their homes by tuning into the Virtual Telescope's live stream or capturing the event through special instructions provided for photography. answers: Look up at the sky on Jan. 31 and you may witness a sight unseen for 150 years. For the first time since 1866, a total lunar eclipse will occur with the blue moon, or second full moon of the month, which—like the one visible on New Year's Day—will also be a supermoon. Got all that? When the moon is at or near the closest point to Earth in its orbit (aka, a supermoon), it appears 14% bigger and 30% brighter than full moons that occur at the farthest point in the moon's orbit, though the moon will lose brightness as it enters Earth's shadow, according to NASA. Because of the way Earth's atmosphere bends light, the eclipsed moon will take on a reddish hue, something often referred to as a blood moon, making this rare celestial event "a super blue blood moon eclipse," according to the Miami Herald. The next blue moon eclipse won't occur until 2028. The eclipse will last for 3.5 hours, with the total eclipse stretching for 77 minutes, reports Sky & Telescope. Those along the Pacific Rim from Alaska and northwestern Canada to central and eastern Asia, Indonesia, New Zealand, and Australia will get the best view of totality during the middle of the night. However, partial phases of the eclipse should be visible under a clear sky in central North America, western Asia, India, the Middle East and eastern Europe, per Space.com. North American viewers should look up as the moon sets on the morning of Jan. 31, while those on the opposite side of the world should see a partial eclipse as the moon rises. Not in an ideal viewing area? The Virtual Telescope plans to livestream the total eclipse from Australia, which you can watch here, per Quartz. (Bogus glasses damaged a solar eclipse viewer's eyes.)

answers: The final round of voting began in Egypt today, and it looks like the Muslim Brotherhood could walk off with a controlling majority of seats in Parliament's lower house. The Muslim Brotherhood's Freedom and Justice Party, the country's mainstream Islamist party, had already won a high percentage of the seats awarded in the first and second rounds of voting. Two of the nine provinces voting today are Brotherhood strongholds, where some of the party's most well-known candidates are running, the New York Times reports. A plurality, not a majority, was originally predicted for the Freedom and Justice Party. A majority would allow the party to govern alone, but the Brotherhood has repeatedly said it plans to form a coalition government, and has aligned itself with more liberal parties rather than the ultraconservative Salafis, who are in second place with up to 25% of the seats so far. Also today, prosecutors began presenting their case against former Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak, Bloomberg notes. His trial resumed last week after a two-month break; state TV today showed Mubarak being carried to and from the courtroom on a gurney. "He deserves an end of humiliation and indignity," said the chief prosecutor, according to the AP.

answers: Police in Vermont say a car ended up almost vertical when the driver swerved quickly in response to her GPS ordering her to "turn around."
